elements.content: The need for enhanced energy storage and improved catalysts has led researchers to explore advanced functional materials for sustainable energy production and storage. Herein, we demonstrate a reductive electrosynthesis approach to prepare a layer-by-layer (LbL) assembled trimetallic Fe–Co–Ni metal–organic framework (MOF) in which the metal cations within each layer or at the interface of the two layers are linked to one another by bridging 2-amino-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid linkers. Tailoring catalytically active sites in an LbL fashion affords a highly porous material that exhibits excellent trifunctional electrocatalytic activities toward the hydrogen evolution reaction (η j=10 = 116 mV), oxygen evolution reaction (η j=10 = 254 mV), as well as oxygen reduction reaction (half-wave potential = 0.75 V vs reference hydrogen electrode) in alkaline solutions. The dispersion-corrected density functional theory calculations suggest that the prominent catalytic activity of the LbL MOF toward the HER, OER, and ORR is due to the initial negative adsorption energy of water on the metal nodes and the elongated O–H bond length of the H2O molecule. The Fe–Co–Ni MOF-based Zn–air battery exhibits a remarkable energy storage performance and excellent cycling stability of over 700 cycles that outperform the commercial noble metal benchmarks. When assembled in an asymmetric device configuration, the activated carbon||Fe–Co–Ni MOF supercapacitor provides a superb specific energy and a power of up to 56.2 W h kg–1 and 42.2 kW kg–1, respectively. This work offers not only a novel approach to prepare an LbL assembled multimetallic MOF but also provides a benchmark for a multifunctional electrocatalyst for water splitting and Zn–air batteries.

elements.content: Daily power supplied by renewable energy sources is several thousand times more than the power required to fuel the world, but is intermittent in nature. For example, the amount of solar energy that strikes the earth every ∼80 min (∼5.73 × 1020 J) is approximately equivalent to the total amount of energy that was consumed on the planet in 2020 (∼5.8 × 1020 J). Thus, to relieve the global energy crisis, it is indispensable to store the energy harvested from renewable sources for times when the sun is not shining and the wind is not blowing. This energy can be either stored in electrochemical energy storage devices, namely batteries and electrochemical capacitors, or in chemical bonds, such as splitting water into hydrogen and oxygen as energy carriers (2H2O → O2 + 2H2). Storing energy in batteries and electrochemical capacitors demands the development of advanced energy storage materials. The water-splitting reaction is also a thermodynamically difficult process (requiring an enthalpy, ΔH°, of 286 kJ mol–1 at ambient temperature and pressure) for which high-performance electrocatalysts are vital.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Daily power supplied by renewable energy sources is several thousand times more than the power required to fuel the world, but is intermittent in nature. For example, the amount of solar energy that strikes the earth every ~80 min (~5.73 × 1020 J) is approximately equivalent to the total amount of energy that was consumed on the planet in 2020 (~5.8 × 1020 J). Thus, to relieve the global energy crisis, it is indispensable to store the energy harvested from renewable sources for times when the sun is not shining and the wind is not blowing. This energy can be either stored in electrochemical energy storage devices, namely batteries and electrochemical capacitors, or in chemical bonds, such as splitting water into hydrogen and oxygen as energy carriers (2H2O → O2 + 2H2). Storing energy in batteries and electrochemical capacitors demands the development of advanced energy storage materials. The water-splitting reaction is also a thermodynamically difficult process (requiring an enthalpy, ΔH°, of 286 kJ mol-1 at ambient temperature and pressure) for which high-performance electrocatalysts are vital.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) as an emerging class of ordered crystalline materials with tailorable topology, functionality, porosity, and electrical properties have enjoyed tremendous popularity in a variety of value-added applications including water harvesting from the air, gas storage, targeted drug delivery and biomedicine, and energy sectors, to mention just a few. One of the most important applications among the diverse proposed applications for MOFs is their implementation in energy storage and conversion systems as their skeleton offers effective electron transport highways and an ordered porous architecture that ensures ultrafast evolution and escape of H2 and O2 bubbles. Despite the excellent catalytic activities of precious metals such as Pt, Ir, and Ru for water-splitting reactionsthe hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), the exorbitant cost and scarcity of the noble metals have severely restricted their widespread application. In addition, the energy efficiency of metal–air batteries is mainly determined by the redox reactions of the air cathode that demand the development of efficient, yet cost-effective, durable, and earth-abundant, bifunctional electrocatalysts for both the ORR and the OER.

One of the most important applications among the diverse proposed applications for MOFs is their implementation in energy storage and conversion systems as their skeleton offers effective electron transport highways and an ordered porous architecture that ensures ultrafast evolution and escape of H2 and O2 bubbles. elements.content: Although composites based on mixed-metal MOFs are excellent electrocatalysts for key chemical processes, it still remains a big challenge and sometimes impossible to incorporate multiple metals into the same crystal structure of a MOF with high control over the disposition of the metal elements. Among a vast variety of techniques that have been developed during the past few years for the synthesis of MOFs, electrochemical methods stand out as one of the most promising approaches because of; (i) mild synthesis conditions (e.g., room temperature and pressure), (ii) a short synthesis time (a few minutes), (iii) the possibility for real-time monitoring the synthesis process, (iv) fine control over the electrosynthesis parameters, (v) potential for large-scale production, and more importantly (vi) direct interfacing of MOFs with surfaces, which is a prerequisite for many of the anticipated applications such as energy storage and conversion, catalysis, gas separation, and electrochemical sensors, among others.

elements.content: In this study, we report a controllable electrodeposition approach for the in situ growth of a trimetallic Fe–Co–Ni MOF on Ni foam in a unique Fe–Co–Ni trilayer architecture. Actually, the three complementary aspects that have effectively been pursued over the past two decades, namely (i) establishing a new synthetic method, (ii) designing new MOF structures, and (iii) opening new avenues for their practical applications, have been met, simultaneously. This versatile layer-by-layer (LbL) assembly offers a route to the fabrication of architecture-tailored multimetallic thin-film electrodes with electrocatalytic properties that go beyond what is possible for a mixed-metal MOF prepared using a mixture of different metal precursors. The obtained single-phase trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF preserves high crystallinity, hierarchical porosity, and chemical stability, thus resulting in facilitated mass transport and easily accessible active sites. The trimetallic Fe–Co–Ni MOF exhibits excellent performance as the HER, OER, and ORR electrocatalyst with low overpotentials (η) of 116 and 254 mV to reach a current density of 10 mA cm–2 for HER and OER, respectively, and an ORR half-wave potential of 750 mV versus reference hydrogen electrode (RHE). This trifunctional catalytic activity of a pure MOF material, supported by the density functional theory (DFT) calculations, is of paramount importance because; (1) despite the exciting progress made in the synthesis of monofunctional electrocatalysts, the development of bifunctional and trifunctional electrocatalysts has just begun and faces many challenges and (2) while MOF-based composites and MOF-derived materials are frequently used in electrocatalysis, direct electrochemical applications of pure MOFs are still in their infancy. A rechargeable Zn–air battery assembled by using a bifunctional OER–ORR electrocatalyst as the air cathode delivers an excellent power density of 161 mW cm–2 and an outstanding specific energy of ∼945 W h kgZn –1. Moreover, an asymmetric supercapacitor-battery hybrid device (AC||Fe–Co–Ni MOF, AC = activated carbon) delivers a specific capacity of 60 mA h g–1. This study represents a breakthrough in the synthesis of LbL assembled MOFs with synergistic effects between the constituent non-precious metals, exceptional trifunctional catalytic performances toward HER, OER, and ORR, and outstanding energy storage performances that open up new avenues for advanced energy storage and conversion devices.

elements.content: The Pt/C catalyst (20 wt %, with an average particle size of ≤5.0 nm, loaded on graphitized carbon) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. All the other chemicals were purchased from Merck or Sigma-Aldrich and were used without further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Chemicals and Reagents

The Pt/C catalyst (20 wt %, with an average particle size of ≤5.0 nm, loaded on graphitized carbon) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. All the other chemicals were purchased from Merck or Sigma-Aldrich and were used without further purification.

elements.content: The crystallographic characteristics of the samples were collected using a powder X-ray diffractometer (Philips X’pert diffractometer) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) generated at 40 kV and 30 mA with a step size of 0.04° s–1. The XRD patterns were analyzed and simulated with Xpert and Vesta software. FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet FT-IR 100 spectrometer using KBr pellets. Dispersive Raman spectra were obtained on an Almega Thermo Nicolet Raman spectrometer. The inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP–OES) measurements were performed using a Varian ICP–OES VISTA-PRO CCD instrument. Elemental analyses (CHNO) were conducted using an Elementar Vario MAX element analyzer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses of the samples were performed on a VG Microtech instrument consisting of an XR3E2 X-ray source and a Twin anode (Al Kα = 1486.6 eV). The core level spectra were analyzed using CasaXPS software. Morphological and topological characterizations of the materials were carried out using a field-emission scanning electron microscope (Philips), and elemental analysis of the samples was conducted using an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (as an attachment to an SEM instrument). High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images, elemental mapping, selected area electron diffraction patterns, and TEM–EDS spectra of the materials were obtained using an FEI Tecnai G2 F20 SuperTwin TEM instrument (accelerating voltage: 200 kV). The electrochemical tests to evaluate the activity of the different materials were carried out using a BioLogic SP-300 potentiostat/galvanostat (BioLogic, France) controlled via EC-Lab v11.36 software. Hydrodynamic voltammetry with a rotating disc electrode (RDE) was conducted using a Princeton Applied Research instrument (supplied by Ametek) controlled via EC-Lab v11.36 software. For evaluation of the electrocatalytic properties of the materials for the OER/HER/ORR, all the potentials collected with reference to a double-junction Ag/AgCl reference electrode were converted to a RHE scale, where E RHE = E Ag/AgCl + 0.197 V + 0.059 pH. The absolute values of the OER and HER overpotentials were obtained as ηOER = |E – 1.23| and ηHER = |E – 0|, respectively. EIS studies were conducted under open circuit potentials by sweeping the AC frequency from 100 kHz to 10 mHz, and the experimental data were fit using ZFit in EC-Lab software. Electrochemical water-splitting measurements were conducted using a three-electrode cell comprising a double-junction Ag/AgCl reference electrode, a Pt plate counter electrode, and a glassy carbon disk working electrode (0.159 cm2) modified with a catalyst layer. A Solartron 1470A multichannel battery test unit (Solartron Analytical, UK) equipped with Cell Test software (v. 3.5.0) was used for cycling stability measurements.

elements.content: A LbL assembled trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF was electrosynthesized in a conventional three-electrode cell configuration comprising a piece of nickel foam (1 × 1 cm2) as a working electrode, a platinum plate counter electrode, and a double-junction Ag/AgCl filled with KClO4 as a reference electrode (Figure S1). Nickel foam pieces were pretreated with 3.0 M HCl, acetone, and ethanol for a few minutes each and then rinsed thoroughly with doubly distilled water. Stock solutions of each metal precursor were prepared in 50:50 vol % of DMF/H2O as follows: solution 1: Fe­(NO3)3·9H2O (2.8 mM), 2-amino-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC-NH2, 2.8 mM), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, 0.09 M), and KNO3 (2.8 mM); solution 2: Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (5.6 mM), BDC-NH2 (5.6 mM), CTAB (0.09 M), and KNO3 (5.6 mM); and solution 3: Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O (5.6 mM), BDC-NH2 (5.6 mM), CTAB (0.09 M), and KNO3 (5.6 mM). Electrosynthesis of Fe–Co–Ni MOF (as outlined in Figure S1) was performed via a constant potential method by applying a reductive potential step of −1.5 V versus Ag/AgCl (KClO4) for 5 min at room temperature in solutions 1, 2, and 3, respectively. After electrosynthesis of the Fe MOF as a first layer, the electrode was rinsed with distilled water and then transferred to the next precursor solution for the synthesis of the second (Co) and third (Ni) layers. The mixed metal Fe–Co–Ni MOF was also electrosynthesized from a solution containing a mixture of all three metal precursors as well as the linker and the CTAB surfactant that serves as a basis for comparing the performance of the LbL assembled Fe–Co–Ni MOF. Note that the DMF/H2O ratio, CTAB concentration, and reductive potential were all optimized, Figures S2–S4. The electrodeposition time was also optimized to ∼6 min so as to obtain a suitable mass loading (∼1.0 mg cm–2) of the catalyst/active material without peeling off from the substrate surface.
elements.clean_text:
Electrosynthesis of Fe-Co-Ni MOF

A LbL assembled trilayer Fe-Co-Ni MOF was electrosynthesized in a conventional three-electrode cell configuration comprising a piece of nickel foam (1 × 1 cm2) as a working electrode, a platinum plate counter electrode, and a double-junction Ag/AgCl filled with KClO4 as a reference electrode (Figure S1). Nickel foam pieces were pretreated with 3.0 M HCl, acetone, and ethanol for a few minutes each and then rinsed thoroughly with doubly distilled water. Stock solutions of each metal precursor were prepared in 50:50 vol % of DMF/H2O as follows: solution 1: Fe(NO3)3⋅9H2O (2.8 mM), 2-amino-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC-NH2, 2.8 mM), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, 0.09 M), and KNO3 (2.8 mM); solution 2: Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (5.6 mM), BDC-NH2 (5.6 mM), CTAB (0.09 M), and KNO3 (5.6 mM); and solution 3: Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (5.6 mM), BDC-NH2 (5.6 mM), CTAB (0.09 M), and KNO3 (5.6 mM). Electrosynthesis of Fe-Co-Ni MOF (as outlined in Figure S1) was performed via a constant potential method by applying a reductive potential step of -1.5 V versus Ag/AgCl (KClO4) for 5 min at room temperature in solutions 1, 2, and 3, respectively. After electrosynthesis of the Fe MOF as a first layer, the electrode was rinsed with distilled water and then transferred to the next precursor solution for the synthesis of the second (Co) and third (Ni) layers. The mixed metal Fe-Co-Ni MOF was also electrosynthesized from a solution containing a mixture of all three metal precursors as well as the linker and the CTAB surfactant that serves as a basis for comparing the performance of the LbL assembled Fe-Co-Ni MOF. Note that the DMF/H2O ratio, CTAB concentration, and reductive potential were all optimized, Figures S2-S4. The electrodeposition time was also optimized to ~6 min so as to obtain a suitable mass loading (~1.0 mg cm-2) of the catalyst/active material without peeling off from the substrate surface.

elements.content: A Zn–air battery was assembled with a homemade electrochemical cell. The Zn powder with a diameter of 0.3–1.5 mm was used as the anode. The current collector of the positive electrode was a piece of Ni foam the inner side of which was coated with the Fe–Co–Ni MOF catalyst and its outer side was coated with a gas diffusion layer (GDL). For the GDL, carbon nanotube (CNT), activated carbon (AC), and carbon black (CB) with CNT/AC/CB ratios of 10:2.5:1 were dispersed in a mixed solution containing 100 μL of ethanol and 10 μL of PTFE (40 wt. %). The well-stirred slurry was coated on the outer side of the Ni foam sheet and then left to dry. The mass loading of Fe–Co–Ni MOF was ∼1.0 mg cm–2 for all the catalyst electrodes. The electrolyte was a ZnO saturated 6.0 M KOH solution. Similarly, an air cathode using a commercial Pt/C + RuO2 (a Pt/RuO2 ratio of 1:1, ∼1 mg cm–2 of Ni foam) catalyst was also fabricated for comparison purposes.
elements.clean_text:
Device Fabrication

Zn-Air Battery Assembly

A Zn-air battery was assembled with a homemade electrochemical cell. The Zn powder with a diameter of 0.3-1.5 mm was used as the anode. The current collector of the positive electrode was a piece of Ni foam the inner side of which was coated with the Fe-Co-Ni MOF catalyst and its outer side was coated with a gas diffusion layer (GDL). For the GDL, carbon nanotube (CNT), activated carbon (AC), and carbon black (CB) with CNT/AC/CB ratios of 10:2.5:1 were dispersed in a mixed solution containing 100 μL of ethanol and 10 μL of PTFE (40 wt. %). The well-stirred slurry was coated on the outer side of the Ni foam sheet and then left to dry. The mass loading of Fe-Co-Ni MOF was ~1.0 mg cm-2 for all the catalyst electrodes. The electrolyte was a ZnO saturated 6.0 M KOH solution. Similarly, an air cathode using a commercial Pt/C + RuO2 (a Pt/RuO2 ratio of 1:1, ~1 mg cm-2 of Ni foam) catalyst was also fabricated for comparison purposes.

elements.content: An asymmetric supercapacitor–battery hybrid device was fabricated by using the AC negative electrode, Fe–Co–Ni MOF positive electrode, and a Cellgard M824 separator in a 3.0 M KOH electrolyte. The negative electrode was prepared based on our previous reports by blending AC, CB, and PTFE with a mass ratio of 85:10:5 in ethanol. Then, the slurry was uniformly coated onto nickel foam (1 × 1 cm2) and dried in an oven at 60 °C. Before device assembly, the charges (Q) stored on each of the negative and positive electrodes were balanced by changing the mass loading of the two electrodes according to the charge balance principle. Herein, the mass loading of the positive and negative electrodes was optimized at 1.0 and 2.0 mg, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Supercapacitor-Battery Hybrid Device Fabrication

An asymmetric supercapacitor-battery hybrid device was fabricated by using the AC negative electrode, Fe-Co-Ni MOF positive electrode, and a Cellgard M824 separator in a 3.0 M KOH electrolyte. The negative electrode was prepared based on our previous reports by blending AC, CB, and PTFE with a mass ratio of 85:10:5 in ethanol. Then, the slurry was uniformly coated onto nickel foam (1 × 1 cm2) and dried in an oven at 60 °C. Before device assembly, the charges (Q) stored on each of the negative and positive electrodes were balanced by changing the mass loading of the two electrodes according to the charge balance principle. Herein, the mass loading of the positive and negative electrodes was optimized at 1.0 and 2.0 mg, respectively.

elements.content: In order to understand some structural properties of the synthesized MOFs and reveal a mechanism for the promotion of the catalytic activities, first-principles calculations were performed. To optimize the geometry of the MOF structures and study the H2O adsorption, dispersion-corrected DFT (DFT-D3) calculations were performed at the spin-polarized level using the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof hybrid functional (PBE0). The LANL2DZ basis set was applied for the transition metals (Fe, Co, and Ni), and the 6-31G­(d) basis set was used for the other elements (C, O, N, and H) as implemented in the Gaussian 09 program. The electronic structures of the synthesized MOFs including the monolayer Fe MOF, the bilayer Fe–Co MOF, and the trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF were modeled by considering four different structures, where all the structures have three metals, which are linked by six BDC-NH2 linkers (i.e., three metal sites are present in each node, consistent with the structure deposited with CCDC nos. 1016535 and 299265). For example, a trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF is modeled as a molecule that has one Fe, one Co, and one Ni atom in a node linked by six BDC-NH2 linkers. The most relevant structures that were theoretically investigated are those MOFs, which are named 3Fe MOF, 2Fe–Co MOF (or Fe–2Co MOF), and Fe–Co–Ni MOF, which represent the monolayer Fe MOF, bilayer Fe–Co MOF, and trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF, respectively (Figure S5). The adsorption energy (E ads) of individual H2O molecules inside the aforementioned MOFs was calculated using the following equation E ads = E H 2 O / MOF − ( E MOF + E H 2 O ) where E H2O/MOF, E MOF, and E H2O are the total energy of the H2O adsorbed on the MOF complex, the energy of MOF structure, and the energy of a single isolated H2O molecule, respectively. In order to calculate the energies of the highest occupied molecular orbital (E HOMO) and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (E LUMO), the geometry of MOFs was optimized at the PBE0/LANL2DZ­(6-31G­(d)) level of theory and then the HOMO–LUMO energy gap (E gap) was calculated using the following equation E gap = E LUMO − E HOMO
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical Calculations

In order to understand some structural properties of the synthesized MOFs and reveal a mechanism for the promotion of the catalytic activities, first-principles calculations were performed. To optimize the geometry of the MOF structures and study the H2O adsorption, dispersion-corrected DFT (DFT-D3) calculations were performed at the spin-polarized level using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof hybrid functional (PBE0). The LANL2DZ basis set was applied for the transition metals (Fe, Co, and Ni), and the 6-31G(d) basis set was used for the other elements (C, O, N, and H) as implemented in the Gaussian 09 program. The electronic structures of the synthesized MOFs including the monolayer Fe MOF, the bilayer Fe-Co MOF, and the trilayer Fe-Co-Ni MOF were modeled by considering four different structures, where all the structures have three metals, which are linked by six BDC-NH2 linkers (i.e., three metal sites are present in each node, consistent with the structure deposited with CCDC nos. 1016535 and 299265). For example, a trilayer Fe-Co-Ni MOF is modeled as a molecule that has one Fe, one Co, and one Ni atom in a node linked by six BDC-NH2 linkers. The most relevant structures that were theoretically investigated are those MOFs, which are named 3Fe MOF, 2Fe-Co MOF (or Fe-2Co MOF), and Fe-Co-Ni MOF, which represent the monolayer Fe MOF, bilayer Fe-Co MOF, and trilayer Fe-Co-Ni MOF, respectively (Figure S5). The adsorption energy (E ads) of individual H2O molecules inside the aforementioned MOFs was calculated using the following equation 1       E   ads   =   E     H   2   O / MOF   -  (   E   MOF   +   E     H   2   O   )     where E H2O/MOF, E MOF, and E H2O are the total energy of the H2O adsorbed on the MOF complex, the energy of MOF structure, and the energy of a single isolated H2O molecule, respectively. In order to calculate the energies of the highest occupied molecular orbital (E HOMO) and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (E LUMO), the geometry of MOFs was optimized at the PBE0/LANL2DZ(6-31G(d)) level of theory and then the HOMO-LUMO energy gap (E gap) was calculated using the following equation 2       E   gap   =   E   LUMO   -   E   HOMO

elements.content: The Gibbs free energy difference for every reaction step was computed using the following equation Δ G i = E ads + Δ ZPE − T Δ S − e ϕ where E ads is the adsorption energy for each elementary reaction, ΔZPE is the change in zero-point energy, TΔS is the entropic contribution, e is the elementary charge, and φ is the external potential.

elements.content: Because the efficacy of the electrocatalysts largely depends on the proper accessibility of the metal active sites, implementation of catalytically active metals as nodes in MOFs could allow for fine control over the structure–property relationship. In the quest for a new generation of advanced materials for energy storage/conversion applications, the trend is to promote synergistic effects among different metallic species, which has resulted in the development of a variety of bimetallic MOFs such as Ni–Co, Ni–Fe, Fe–Co, and so forth. Because the coupling effects between two metals enhance the electronic occupancy status and thus increase electrocatalytic activity compared to monometallic species, the question arises whether introducing a third metal into the framework could further improve the electrocatalytic efficiency. Thus, attaining a higher level of synergistic effects, which is the key for boosting the electrocatalytic activity, has driven efforts to develop more and more synthetic strategies for preparing bi-, tri-, and multimetallic MOFs. One of the advantages associated with the design of multimetallic MOFs is that different metals can be integrated into a single MOF structure without changing the original topology. More importantly, in such a multimetallic MOF, the role of the metal nodes can be tailored so that different metal centers serve different functions. For example, the catalytic activity of Ni and Co can be combined with favorable charge-transfer kinetics of Fe to provide an electrocatalyst with both low overpotential and high current density. As another example, the adsorption energy of OH, which is too strong for Fe-based species and too weak for Co-based species, falls approximately halfway between the two (i.e., at the top of the volcano-type plot) on the bimetallic Fe–Co surface.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

LbL Assembly of Multifunctional Electrocatalysts

Because the efficacy of the electrocatalysts largely depends on the proper accessibility of the metal active sites, implementation of catalytically active metals as nodes in MOFs could allow for fine control over the structure-property relationship. In the quest for a new generation of advanced materials for energy storage/conversion applications, the trend is to promote synergistic effects among different metallic species, which has resulted in the development of a variety of bimetallic MOFs such as Ni-Co, Ni-Fe, Fe-Co, and so forth. Because the coupling effects between two metals enhance the electronic occupancy status and thus increase electrocatalytic activity compared to monometallic species, the question arises whether introducing a third metal into the framework could further improve the electrocatalytic efficiency. Thus, attaining a higher level of synergistic effects, which is the key for boosting the electrocatalytic activity, has driven efforts to develop more and more synthetic strategies for preparing bi-, tri-, and multimetallic MOFs. One of the advantages associated with the design of multimetallic MOFs is that different metals can be integrated into a single MOF structure without changing the original topology. More importantly, in such a multimetallic MOF, the role of the metal nodes can be tailored so that different metal centers serve different functions. For example, the catalytic activity of Ni and Co can be combined with favorable charge-transfer kinetics of Fe to provide an electrocatalyst with both low overpotential and high current density. As another example, the adsorption energy of OH, which is too strong for Fe-based species and too weak for Co-based species, falls approximately halfway between the two (i.e., at the top of the volcano-type plot) on the bimetallic Fe-Co surface.

elements.content: Inspired by the above considerations, we rationally designed and elaborately tuned the electronic structure and catalytically/electrochemically active sites of the three low-cost and earth-abundant metals (namely Fe, Co, and Ni) into one multifunctional structure (). LbL nanoarchitectonic of the functional building block into a MOF superstructure requires technological and methodological innovation. However, electrosynthesis approaches are best suited for binder-free interfacing of MOFs with electrode surfaces. The electrochemical synthesis of MOFs can be divided into two subgroups: anodic and cathodic deposition. The anodic electrodeposition approach relies on the dissolution of sacrificial metallic anodes to generate metal cations (i.e., M0 → Mn+). The cathodic electrodeposition approach, in contrast, makes use of solution-phase cationic species, thus, making it possible to synthesize multimetallic MOFs. The electrodeposition process, which consists of (i) initial nucleation, (ii) growth of MOF islands, and (iii) intergrowth of the particles to form a compact layer with the desired morphology and thickness, can easily be tailored by changing the solvent, probase material and surfactant, as well as the applied potential (see the Supporting Information for the reductive electrosynthesis details).

elements.content: LbL nanoarchitectonics for preparing multifunctional MOFs. (a) Schematic illustration showing nickel foam (green) coated with trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF (yellow). The macroporous structure of the electrode is essential for improving the ion and electron transport kinetics required for electrocatalytic applications. (b) Magnified view of the microstructure of the electrode showing the sequential deposition of the iron, cobalt, and nickel MOF layers. The high surface area of the MOF along with its open porous structure and good electrical properties enable fast and reversible electrochemical reactions. (c) Cross-sectional SEM image showing the successful growth of the three MOF layers on top of the nickel substrate. (d) As-synthesized material can be directly used as electrocatalysts active in all of the following electrochemical reactions: the OER, the HER, and the ORR. As OER and HER catalysts are essential for catalyzing the overall water-splitting reaction, and OER and ORR processes are key reversible reactions for Zn–air batteries, we further explored the practical application of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF electrocatalyst in these systems, as well as an active material for pseudocapacitive energy storage devices.

elements.content: To demonstrate that the Fe, Co, and Ni MOF layers are piled one on top of one another in an orderly fashion, we recorded top view and cross-sectional FE-SEM images of the trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF (a–c, see also Supporting Information, Figures S6–S8). From the cross-sectional SEM image in c and the corresponding SEM–EDS map presented in d, it can be clearly seen that C, N, and O as constituent elements of the organic linker are evenly distributed throughout the FE-SEM image (except in the bottom part of the image, separated by a dashed yellow line that corresponds to the Ni foam substrate), whereas, Fe, Co, and Ni elements are distributed in distinctly different layers in an LbL assembled fashion. It is evident that a continuous Fe MOF layer (in between the orange and yellow boundaries in the SEM and highlighted in violet in the EDS mapping) is deposited on the Ni foam substrate. The images also show that the Co MOF layer (middle, highlighted in red in the EDS mapping) with a clearly different contrast is deposited in between the Fe MOF (bottom) and Ni MOF (top) layers. All this unequivocally shows the tailored spatial arrangement of the Fe, Co, and Ni MOF layers. From the cross-sectional SEM image, the thickness of the Fe MOF, Co MOF, and Ni MOF layers is estimated to be 1.1, 1.9, and 2.9 μm, respectively. The SEM cross-sectional image combined with the EDS line scan (Figure S9) provide additional evidence for the successful fabrication of an LbL assembled Fe–Co–Ni MOF. EDS line scans reveal that the cross-sectional morphology of the coating can be divided into three different layers; the top Ni layer, the middle Co layer, and the bottom Fe layer. Note that the high signal of Ni at the bottom of the coating stems from the Ni foam substrate.

elements.content: We recorded XRD patterns to determine the crystalline structure of the Fe MOF, the bilayer Fe–Co MOF, and the trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF (e). The XRD pattern of the Fe MOF matches well with the simulated pattern of CPO-10 ({[Mn3(Hatp)2(atp)2]­(H2O)2(DEF)4}n, (atp = 2-aminoterephthalate, DEF = diethylformamide)) with CCDC no. 299265 and Co3(ABDC)3(DMF)4 MOF with CCDC no. 1016535, confirming the successful formation of the Fe MOF as the first layer. The XRD pattern of the bilayer Fe–Co MOF also displays characteristic peaks of the Fe MOF. With the deposition of the Ni MOF on top of the bilayer Fe–Co MOF, the XRD pattern is still in compliance with that of the bilayer Fe–Co MOFs as well as the simulated pattern of BDC-NH2 Fe–Co–Ni MOF. It can be concluded that the Co MOF and subsequently the Ni MOF layers that have been grown on top of the unary Fe MOF layer follow the same crystal structure as the Fe MOF. This result may be due to the similar ionic radius and close electronegativity of Co2+ and Ni2+ with Fe2+, which triggers incorporation of subsequent layers in the same crystalline framework with the Fe layer. The proposed crystalline structures are shown in f,g, which are related to the simulated CPO-10 structure.

elements.content: We conducted XPS to investigate the relative surface concentrations and the chemical environments of the Fe, Co, and Ni elements. Figure S10 shows the full survey spectra of the Fe MOF, the bilayer Fe–Co MOF, and the trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF as well as the one-pot electrosynthesized mixed-metal FeCoNi MOF. The high-resolution core-level XPS spectra of the Fe, Co, and Ni elements, corresponding to the four aforementioned samples, are presented as h–j, respectively. Comparing the core-level XPS spectrum of Fe in the Fe MOF with those of the bilayer Fe–Co MOF and the trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF, it can be clearly seen that the binding energies generally positively shift to higher values by moving from a unary to a binary and to a ternary metal MOF structure. The same trend can also be seen in the XPS spectra of Co by comparing the Co binding energies of the Fe–Co MOF and the Fe–Co–Ni MOF. This can be attributed to the local electronic structure and the changes in the coordination environment of the metal nodes after the introduction of the second and third MOF layers. The positive shift of the binding energies implies higher oxidation states and thus higher oxidative capabilities in catalyzing different electrochemical transformations. Because of the synergistic effects between the constituent metals, this change in the electronic environment is likely to improve the electrocatalytic activities of the MOFs. By comparing the XPS spectra of Fe, Co, and Ni of the trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF with those of the mixed-metal FeCoNi MOF, it can be seen that the binding energies of the trilayer MOF appear at more positive values. These binding energy shifts can be mainly ascribed to the effect of partial electron transfer from the metal nodes to the organic linkers. The trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF exhibits an ordered reticular structure, whereas the mixed-metal MOF displays a less-ordered structure comprised of some metal oxide species as well. While the binding energies of the metal nodes positively shift to higher binding energy values, the peaks of O 1s show a regular shift to lower binding energy values according to the following order: Fe MOF > Fe–Co MOF > Fe–Co–Ni MOF, consistent with that observed for the electrocatalytic activities (Figure S11a). Because of this partial electron transfer, metal nodes with a high valence state and enhanced local electric dipole are formed. Thus, the partially positively charged Fe, Co, and Ni centers serve as electron acceptors, and the partially negative O centers function as proton-acceptor sites. This results in a lower energy barrier during the electrocatalytic process and thus a better catalytic performance. The deconvoluted core level XPS spectra of the C 1s and N 1s are also presented in Figure S11.

elements.content: We also used TEM as one of the most widely used techniques for morphological and structural characterization of materials and the details of which can be found in the Supporting Information (Figures S12 and S13). In addition, we recorded FT-IR and Raman spectra to provide additional pieces of evidence that in all samples, the BDC-NH2 linkers coordinate with the metals to form MOFs (see the Supporting Information for details, Figure S14). Moreover, we conducted ICP–OES and CHNO elemental analyses to measure the actual composition and ratio of the elements in the trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF (Table S1) and to confirm the structural formula of the trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF (C64H48N8FeCoNiO32, note that we assume that Fe, Co, and Ni elements are equally distributed in the trilayer MOF structure).

elements.content: Because the presence and order of the constituent elements are likely to play a role in these catalytic processes, a series of MOFs including monometallic Fe, Co, and Ni MOFs, bimetallic Fe–Co, Co–Fe, Fe–Ni, Ni–Fe, Co–Ni, and Ni–Co MOFs, and trilayer Co–Fe–Ni, Co–Ni–Fe, Fe–Co–Ni, Fe–Ni–Co, Ni–Co–Fe, and Ni–Fe–Co MOFs along with the mixed-metal FeCoNi MOF were synthesized and studied for the best-performance catalyst. As can be seen, trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF demonstrates the best electrochemical performance (see Figure S15 in the Supporting Information for details).
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Applications

Trifunctional Electrocatalysis toward OER, HER, and ORR

Because the presence and order of the constituent elements are likely to play a role in these catalytic processes, a series of MOFs including monometallic Fe, Co, and Ni MOFs, bimetallic Fe-Co, Co-Fe, Fe-Ni, Ni-Fe, Co-Ni, and Ni-Co MOFs, and trilayer Co-Fe-Ni, Co-Ni-Fe, Fe-Co-Ni, Fe-Ni-Co, Ni-Co-Fe, and Ni-Fe-Co MOFs along with the mixed-metal FeCoNi MOF were synthesized and studied for the best-performance catalyst. As can be seen, trilayer Fe-Co-Ni MOF demonstrates the best electrochemical performance (see Figure S15 in the Supporting Information for details).

elements.content: We also analyzed the effect of the BDC-NH2 linker in tuning the catalytic activity of the resulting MOF structures. In this control experiment, we prepared the MOFs using the amino-free BDC linker. Although experimental results and theoretical calculations reported later on for these systems suggest that the metal nodes are the active sites for catalysis, the amine functional group of the linker also plays a critical role in these applications (see Supporting Information, Figure S16). The amine functionalities likely serve as water adsorption sites, where the water molecules form hydrogen bonds (H-bonds) to the amine group. Enhancement of the hydrophilicity of the amino-functionalized MOF structure favors the bubble detachment from the electrode, promotes the charge-transfer rate in the electrode–electrolyte interface, and facilitates the transport of hydrated O2 to the electrochemically active sites, thus leading to a better OER/HER/ORR catalytic activity.

Enhancement of the hydrophilicity of the amino-functionalized MOF structure favors the bubble detachment from the electrode, promotes the charge-transfer rate in the electrode-electrolyte interface, and facilitates the transport of hydrated O2 to the electrochemically active sites, thus leading to a better OER/HER/ORR catalytic activity.

elements.content: To investigate the electrocatalytic performance of the trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF toward overall water splitting, we first evaluated the OER activity in a 1.0 M KOH solution in a standard three-electrode cell setup, using Fe–Co–Ni MOF as the working electrode, double-junction Ag/AgCl as a reference electrode, and a Pt plate as a counter electrode. We converted the data collected with reference to an Ag/AgCl reference electrode to a RHE scale. We also used a binary Fe–Co MOF, a Fe MOF, bare Ni foam, as well as a RuO2 electrode as control samples. a displays linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves of all samples at a scan rate of 5 mV s–1. The OER activity trends are as follows: Fe–Co–Ni MOF > Fe–Co MOF > Fe MOF > Ni foam. The bare Ni foam displays the least OER activity with an overpotential of 440 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm–2 (η10 = 440 mV). Fe MOF displays a better OER activity (η10 = 290 mV). The bilayer Fe–Co MOF shows much better OER activity (η10 = 280 mV) likely because of the synergistic effects between Fe and Co metal centers. The trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF displays the best OER activity (η10 = 254 mV), among all the samples, that is even far greater than that of the RuO2 catalyst (η10 = 318 mV) and superior to most non-noble metal-based electrocatalysts reported in the literature (Table S2). The excellent OER activity of the trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF can be attributed to its well-defined ordered porous structure with useful exploitation of synergistic effects between optimally distributed metal catalysts and a large accessible surface area. The corresponding Tafel slope of the trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF (51.3 mV dec–1) is also lower than those of the bilayer Fe–Co MOF (63.0 mV dec–1) and the Fe MOF (67.7 mV dec–1) catalysts, confirming faster kinetics and more favorable OER activity for the trimetallic Fe–Co–Ni MOF (b). In order to examine the stability and durability of the trimetallic Fe–Co–Ni MOF, we performed long-term (48 h) chronopotentiometry at geometric current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm–2 (c). Interestingly, at both low and high current densities, the Fe–Co–Ni MOF maintains an approximately constant potential for 48 h without any obvious degradation in OER activity. Moreover, comparing the LSV and CV curves for OER before and after 1000 CV cycles at a scan rate of 500 mV s–1 shows quite similar shapes, providing additional support for the excellent stability of the trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF under harsh water-splitting conditions (c inset).

The excellent OER activity of the trilayer Fe-Co-Ni MOF can be attributed to its well-defined ordered porous structure with useful exploitation of synergistic effects between optimally distributed metal catalysts and a large accessible surface area. The corresponding Tafel slope of the trilayer Fe-Co-Ni MOF (51.3 mV dec-1) is also lower than those of the bilayer Fe-Co MOF (63.0 mV dec-1) and the Fe MOF (67.7 mV dec-1) catalysts, confirming faster kinetics and more favorable OER activity for the trimetallic Fe-Co-Ni MOF (b). In order to examine the stability and durability of the trimetallic Fe-Co-Ni MOF, we performed long-term (48 h) chronopotentiometry at geometric current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm-2 (c). Interestingly, at both low and high current densities, the Fe-Co-Ni MOF maintains an approximately constant potential for 48 h without any obvious degradation in OER activity. Moreover, comparing the LSV and CV curves for OER before and after 1000 CV cycles at a scan rate of 500 mV s-1 shows quite similar shapes, providing additional support for the excellent stability of the trilayer Fe-Co-Ni MOF under harsh water-splitting conditions (c inset).

elements.content: We also evaluated the HER performance of the trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF and compared it with those of the bilayer Fe–Co MOF, the Fe MOF, Ni foam, and Pt/C in a 1.0 M KOH electrolyte at a sweep rate of 5 mV s–1 (d). Similar to the OER activity, the HER activity trend of the samples is as follows: Fe–Co–Ni MOF > Fe–Co MOF > Fe MOF > Ni foam. As can be seen, Fe–Co–Ni MOF shows the best catalytic activity toward HER (η10 = 116 mV, that of Pt/C is 74 mV), followed by the Fe–Co MOF (η10 = 131 mV), the Fe MOF (η10 = 161 mV), and the bare Ni foam substrate (η10 = 260 mV). The Tafel slope of the trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF catalyst for the HER (56 mV dec–1) is also lower than those of the bilayer Fe–Co MOF (62 mV dec–1) and the Fe MOF (67 mV dec–1), demonstrating the favorable reaction rates in the HER process (e). Additionally, a long-term (48 h) chronoamperometry test at a constant potential of −0.10 V versus RHE revealed that the electrocatalytic HER activity can be maintained for at least 48 h (Figure S17a). The LSV curves recorded before and after 48 h (Figure S17b) show a negligible potential shift, demonstrating excellent HER catalytic performance of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF compared with other reported non-precious electrocatalysts (Table S3).

HER Activity

We also evaluated the HER performance of the trilayer Fe-Co-Ni MOF and compared it with those of the bilayer Fe-Co MOF, the Fe MOF, Ni foam, and Pt/C in a 1.0 M KOH electrolyte at a sweep rate of 5 mV s-1 (d). Similar to the OER activity, the HER activity trend of the samples is as follows: Fe-Co-Ni MOF > Fe-Co MOF > Fe MOF > Ni foam. As can be seen, Fe-Co-Ni MOF shows the best catalytic activity toward HER (η10 = 116 mV, that of Pt/C is 74 mV), followed by the Fe-Co MOF (η10 = 131 mV), the Fe MOF (η10 = 161 mV), and the bare Ni foam substrate (η10 = 260 mV). The Tafel slope of the trilayer Fe-Co-Ni MOF catalyst for the HER (56 mV dec-1) is also lower than those of the bilayer Fe-Co MOF (62 mV dec-1) and the Fe MOF (67 mV dec-1), demonstrating the favorable reaction rates in the HER process (e). Additionally, a long-term (48 h) chronoamperometry test at a constant potential of -0.10 V versus RHE revealed that the electrocatalytic HER activity can be maintained for at least 48 h (Figure S17a). The LSV curves recorded before and after 48 h (Figure S17b) show a negligible potential shift, demonstrating excellent HER catalytic performance of the Fe-Co-Ni MOF compared with other reported non-precious electrocatalysts (Table S3).

elements.content: Considering the excellent OER and HER activities, we examined the combination of OER and HER and the potential difference (ΔE OER–HER) between them in a 2E cell setup. The LSV curves for OER and HER show that a potential difference of 1.60 V is required to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm–2 for the Fe–Co–Ni MOF-based cell, which is much lower than those obtained for the Fe–Co MOF (ΔE OER–HER = 1.65 V), the Fe MOF (ΔE OER–HER = 1.67 V), and Ni foam (ΔE OER–HER = 1.93 V) based cells, and even better than that of the benchmark Pt/C(−)||RuO2(+) electrolyzer (ΔE OER–HER = 1.62 V) as well (f). The excellent water-splitting activity of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF catalyst is well ahead of those of most of the other non-noble metal electrocatalysts reported in the literature (g, Table S4). Interestingly, it delivers an overall water-splitting cell voltage of 1.60 and 1.63 V in a two-electrode cell compartment at current densities of 10 and 15 mA cm–2, respectively (h). To assess the long-term stability and durability of the cell, we recorded the chronopotentiometry response of the two-electrode electrolyzer at a current density of 10 mA cm–2 for 150 h (Figure S18). The plot shows that a voltage of 1.6 V remains almost constant over the course of the working days. We also compared the long-term stability of the MOF-based electrolyzers as well as the Pt/C||RuO2 cell by recording the chronoamperograms for 150 h at a constant overpotential of 1.8 V. The rate of current density loss for the Fe–Co–Ni MOF||Fe–Co–Ni MOF cell (7% after 150 h) is significantly lower than those for Fe–Co MOF||Fe–Co MOF (16%) and Fe MOF||Fe MOF (24%) cells, and much better than that of the state-of-the-art Pt/C||RuO2 (43%) cells (Figure S19). The survival of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF in this long-term stability test is due in part to the strong covalent conjugation of the MOF structures on the Ni foam substrate, as well as the coordination geometry between metals and ligands. Note also that the MOF structures presented in this study are solvent-free structures (i.e., metal sites are all full-coordinated by ligands) that exhibit higher stability than that of solvent-coordinated counterparts. To further investigate the reasons behind the long-term stability of the trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF, we assessed the morphological and structural changes of the active materials before and after the HER and OER using FE-SEM (Figures S20–S22) as well as the XPS (Figure S23) and XRD (Figure S24) methods. Postoperation analyses of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF after 2 and 150 h of the HER and OER processes reveal that their morphologies are almost unchanged (Figure S20), and the surface composition is preserved (Figures S21 and S22). However, the XPS measurement after 150 h of continuous HER/OER indicates that the peak intensity ratio of the trivalent species slightly increased, while the binding energies are almost unchanged. This can be likely attributed to the generation of the (oxy)­hydroxides during catalysis, consistent with previously reported studies. Partial transformation in the structure of the trilayer MOF after the long-term operation was also verified by XRD measurements. Although the XRD pattern of the MOF is preserved, the postoperation pattern reveals small changes that can be attributed to enriched trivalent metal species. Note that the stable catalytic activity is critically important for practical applications, which is rarely reported for MOF-based electrocatalysts. i displays a photograph illustrating that hydrogen and oxygen bubbles are produced on the surface of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF electrodes operating at a constant current density of 15 mA cm–2 in the assembled electrolyzer (Video S1). For a better understanding of the reasons behind the excellent catalytic performance of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF catalyst, we evaluated the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) and turn over frequency (TOF) of the catalyst. The ECSA of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF electrode, which can be estimated by evaluating the double layer capacitance (C dl) of the non-faradaic region of the CV at different scan rates (Figure S25), is 111.2 cm2, which is far higher than those of the Fe–Co MOF (102.7 cm2), the Fe MOF (16.1 cm2), and the mixed-metal FeCoNi MOF (75.7 cm2). It should be mentioned that the mass loadings of the trilayer MOF electrode are almost the same as those of the Fe–Co MOF and the Fe MOF electrodes, thus the huge difference in ECSA of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF electrode compared to the other two electrodes cannot be explained simply by the film thickness, instead, it is due to the high electrochemically active center density of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF that benefits from the synergistic effects between the active centers and the fast electron transfer rate within the electrode and at the electrode–electrolyte interface.

elements.content: The TOF is another figure of merit demonstrating enhanced catalytic activity (Figure S26). The highest TOF at an overpotential of 400 mV (0.407 ± 0.016 s–1) also belongs to the trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF. These results demonstrate that the high ECSA and TOF of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF catalyst in combination with the synergistic effects between the metal active sites explain the excellent water-splitting performance (facile evolution of the O2 and H2 bubbles and ultrafast gas bubble escape rate) of the catalyst.

elements.content: We also combined the results obtained from the LSV analyses and the proposed mechanisms in the literature to reveal the processes involved in the HER mechanism. It is generally accepted that a Tafel slope close to 120, 40, or 30 mV dec–1 demonstrates that the rate-determining step of the HER process is controlled by Volmer, Heyrovsky, or Tafel steps, respectively. The value of the Tafel slope (55 mV dec–1) indicates that the catalytic process is likely controlled by the Volmer–Heyrovsky mechanism. elements.clean_text: We also combined the results obtained from the LSV analyses and the proposed mechanisms in the literature to reveal the processes involved in the HER mechanism. It is generally accepted that a Tafel slope close to 120, 40, or 30 mV dec-1 demonstrates that the rate-determining step of the HER process is controlled by Volmer, Heyrovsky, or Tafel steps, respectively. The value of the Tafel slope (55 mV dec-1) indicates that the catalytic process is likely controlled by the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism. Thus, the HER reactions under alkaline conditions can be expressed as:

elements.content:
Volmer reaction (bond formation step) M + H 2 O + e − → M − H * + O H −

Heyrovsky reaction (bond cleavage step) M − H * + H 2 O + e − → M + H 2 + O H − here, M is the catalytically active sites, namely Fe, Co, and Ni involved in the reactions and * represents adsorption of the species on the metal active sites. All the results above clearly support that the trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF performs as an efficient and stable electrocatalyst for overall water splitting. The excellent OER/HER activities of the proposed trilayer MOF structure can be ascribed to the following characteristics: (1) tailoring the morphology of the particles so that mass transport occurs more readily within the electrocatalyst. (2) Interfacial engineering of the catalytically active sites so that the electrocatalysts cooperate synergistically toward the OER/HER reactions. The adsorption energy of the OER and HER intermediates is mainly determined by the energy levels of the metal 3d orbitals. For example, the adsorption energy of OH is too strong on the Fe-based species (thus suppresses the desorption in the Heyrovsky step, ) and too weak on the Ni and Co (so that limits the rate of the Volmer step, ). However, the catalytic activity of the bimetallic or trimetallic species toward both Heyrovsky and Volmer steps is better than that of individual species, likely because each of the catalytically active sites plays a specific role in different intermediate steps. (3) The reticular chemistry of the MOF architectures facilitates mass transport and thus enables full exposure of the active sites for catalytic activity. (4) Direct electrodeposition of the catalyst on a Ni foam substrate makes and maintains intimate contact between them without a binder. Collectively, benefiting from these advantageous properties puts the trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF among the most outstanding water-splitting electrocatalysts.

elements.content: We conducted DFT calculations to gain further insights into the origin of the outstanding catalytic activities of the synthesized MOFs, their electronic structure, and the adsorption energy of the H2O molecules into their structures. According to the XRD patterns of the synthesized MOFs (e), they match with the diffraction patterns of the CPO-10 and Co3(ABDC)3(DMF)4 MOF structures. We considered four structural models for the MOFs (Figure S5). The optimized bond lengths of Fe–O, Co–O, and Ni–O are 1.93, 1.96, and 2.04 Å, which are in good agreement with those reported in previous theoretical and experimental works. Also, the distances between Fe–Fe, Fe–Co, Co–Co, and Co–Ni are about 3.39, 3.34, 3.26, and 3.35 Å, respectively, which are larger than the kinetic diameter of the H2O molecule (2.65 Å). The latter implies that H2O could penetrate into the metal active centers of the MOFs. The interaction of the H2O molecule with the MOF structures is quantitatively illustrated by the adsorption energy using , which reflects the capability of the MOF structure for purposes of water splitting. E ads is found to be −0.37, −0.45, −0.51, and −1.06 eV for H2O adsorption on 3Fe MOF, 2Fe–Co MOF, Fe–2Co MOF, and Fe–Co–Ni MOF, respectively. The most negative value of E ads on the Fe–Co–Ni MOF indicates the strongest interaction of the H2O molecule on its surface, which is due to the positive charge of the Ni atom (+1.01e, e is the unit of electric charge). This charge is approximately +0.20e larger than those of Fe and Co (see ). We further used molecular surface electrostatic potential (ESP) and HOMO–LUMO energy gap (E gap, ) to understand the origin of the H2O adsorption on the aforementioned MOFs. According to the ESP results (a), the positive ESP (blue color) on the Ni atom is larger than those on the Fe and Co atoms, whereas the O atom in H2O exhibits a strong negative ESP (red color). The latter leads to a strong interaction between the Ni atom and the O atom of the H2O molecule. Furthermore, the calculated E gap values for 3Fe MOF, 2Fe–Co MOF, Fe–2Co MOF, and Fe–Co–Ni MOF are 3.04, 2.89, 1.86, and 0.36 eV, respectively (b). The small band gap of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF corresponds to a strong interaction of this MOF with the H2O molecule, confirming the superior catalytic activity of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF. In all the studied MOFs, the O–H bond length of the H2O molecule elongated up to ∼0.06 Å when a water molecule is adsorbed. Also, the corresponding stretching vibrational frequency displays a 301.25 cm–1 red shift, and the H–O–H angle exceeds 106.0° because of the interaction between the lone pairs and the metal nodes (Figure S27, for a water molecule, the bond length is 0.96 Å and the bond angle is 104.5°). These are all signatures of the MOFs’ capability (especially the Fe–Co–Ni MOF structure) for catalyzing the water-splitting process.

We conducted DFT calculations to gain further insights into the origin of the outstanding catalytic activities of the synthesized MOFs, their electronic structure, and the adsorption energy of the H2O molecules into their structures. According to the XRD patterns of the synthesized MOFs (e), they match with the diffraction patterns of the CPO-10 and Co3(ABDC)3(DMF)4 MOF structures. We considered four structural models for the MOFs (Figure S5). The optimized bond lengths of Fe-O, Co-O, and Ni-O are 1.93, 1.96, and 2.04 Å, which are in good agreement with those reported in previous theoretical and experimental works. Also, the distances between Fe-Fe, Fe-Co, Co-Co, and Co-Ni are about 3.39, 3.34, 3.26, and 3.35 Å, respectively, which are larger than the kinetic diameter of the H2O molecule (2.65 Å). The latter implies that H2O could penetrate into the metal active centers of the MOFs. The interaction of the H2O molecule with the MOF structures is quantitatively illustrated by the adsorption energy using , which reflects the capability of the MOF structure for purposes of water splitting. E ads is found to be -0.37, -0.45, -0.51, and -1.06 eV for H2O adsorption on 3Fe MOF, 2Fe-Co MOF, Fe-2Co MOF, and Fe-Co-Ni MOF, respectively. The most negative value of E ads on the Fe-Co-Ni MOF indicates the strongest interaction of the H2O molecule on its surface, which is due to the positive charge of the Ni atom (+1.01e, e is the unit of electric charge). According to the ESP results (a), the positive ESP (blue color) on the Ni atom is larger than those on the Fe and Co atoms, whereas the O atom in H2O exhibits a strong negative ESP (red color). elements.content: DFT calculations of the MOF structures. (a) Molecular surface ESP of the studied models of MOFs; 3Fe MOF, 2Fe–Co MOF, Fe–2Co MOF, and Fe–Co–Ni MOF. (b) Energy of the highest occupied molecular orbital (E HOMO), lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (E LUMO), and the energy gap (E gap) of the studied models are shown for each case in units of eV. Note that three metal sites are present in each node, thus, for example, the Fe–2Co MOF indicates that one metal site of the node is Fe and the other two metal sites are Co. This is to simplify the DFT calculations for treating large molecular systems. (c,d) Microkinetic modeling of the electrocatalytic reaction processes along with the calculated free energy diagrams for (c) OER and (d) HER on the surface of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF catalyst.

Furthermore, we performed the density of states (DOS) analysis to reveal the contribution of each element (Fe, Co, and Ni) in electronic properties for the studied MOFs (Figure S28). Because electrons just below the Fermi level can be excited to the conduction band, the higher DOS around the Fermi level of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF compared to those of the 3Fe MOF, 2Fe–Co MOF, and Fe–2Co MOF reflects the superior electrical conductivity of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF. The results of the experimental studies on the electrical conductivities of the MOF structures are presented in Figure S29 in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, we performed the density of states (DOS) analysis to reveal the contribution of each element (Fe, Co, and Ni) in electronic properties for the studied MOFs (Figure S28). Because electrons just below the Fermi level can be excited to the conduction band, the higher DOS around the Fermi level of the Fe-Co-Ni MOF compared to those of the 3Fe MOF, 2Fe-Co MOF, and Fe-2Co MOF reflects the superior electrical conductivity of the Fe-Co-Ni MOF. The results of the experimental studies on the electrical conductivities of the MOF structures are presented in Figure S29 in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: The OER reaction steps of the water-splitting process start with adsorption of water or OH– anions on the metal active sites to form M–OH* and an electron–hole pair. Deprotonation of M–OH* results in the formation of M–O* along with another electron–hole pair. Thereafter, M–O* reacts with OH– to form an M–OOH* intermediate along with the third electron–hole pair. Subsequently, O2 is produced through the deprotonation of M–OOH*, and the M* (or simply *) active site is regenerated for a new OER cycle. The four produced electron–hole pairs enter the HER process, where an electron–hole pair (H+ + e–) is adsorbed on the M* site and interacts with the other electron–hole pair to produce a H2 molecule. c shows the typical four one-electron/proton reaction pathways of the OER on the Fe–Co–Ni MOF, as well as the corresponding Gibbs free energies (ΔG) of the intermediates for each elementary step (see the Supporting Information for the calculations). In this schematic representation, the active sites (*) over the Fe–Co–Ni MOF are Ni atoms as the topmost layer of the trilayer MOF. The oxygen-containing intermediates adsorbed during the OER process on the active sites are represented as OH*, O*, and OOH*. As can be seen, the rate-determining step is the formation of the *OOH intermediate with the largest energy uphill of 1.95 eV. Note that none of the OER steps is exergonic, as an exergonic process produces reaction intermediates that strongly bind the catalyst surface and poison the active sites (c).

Subsequently, O2 is produced through the deprotonation of M-OOH*, and the M* (or simply *) active site is regenerated for a new OER cycle. Note that none of the OER steps is exergonic, as an exergonic process produces reaction intermediates that strongly bind the catalyst surface and poison the active sites (c).

elements.content: We also evaluated the mechanism of the HER by considering “M* + H2O” as an initial state and “M–H* + H2O” as the second state that results in the H2 production. d shows the optimized structure and the free energy diagram of the HER promoted by the Fe–Co–Ni MOF. For an ideal system, the value of ΔG for the HER should be close to zero. The calculated ΔG for promoting the HER process for external potential values (φ) of 0.00 and 1.23 V is found to be 0.88 and −0.34 eV, respectively. The latter refers to the fact that the adsorption of H over the Fe–Co–Ni MOF is weak without applying a more negative external potential. This negative value, that is close to zero, indicates that the adsorption of hydrogen over the Fe–Co–Ni MOF is possible if one applies a more negative bias (d). Generally, DFT calculations can provide exciting new insights into understanding the catalytic mechanism of water-splitting processes, confirming the robustness of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF catalyst toward the efficient production of oxygen and hydrogen.

elements.content: We also evaluated the ORR activities of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF catalyst as well as the control samples by CV in O2- or N2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte solution. As shown in Figure S30, the Fe–Co–Ni MOF, as well as the Fe–Co MOF and the Fe MOF electrodes, display a featureless quasirectangular CV curve in the N2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte. In contrast, in an O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte, a considerably high current reduction peak emerges at a potential of ∼0.75 V versus RHE. While a relatively limited number of transition metal-based materials have been reported as efficient ORR electrocatalysts, the remarkable ORR activity of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF, as well as the bimetallic Fe–Co MOF and the Fe MOF, is of paramount importance for practical applications. Furthermore, the smaller the amount of the potential gap between ORR and OER, the higher the bifunctional OER/ORR activity will be. ΔE OER–ORR of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF catalyst (which is generally the difference between the OER potential at a current density of 10 mA cm–2 and the half-wave potential of ORR at a rotation speed of 1600 rpm) is 0.73 V (a), which is lower than or comparable to those of other catalysts used in zinc–air batteries and outperforms those of expensive noble metal-based catalysts (Table S5).

ORR Activity

As shown in Figure S30, the Fe-Co-Ni MOF, as well as the Fe-Co MOF and the Fe MOF electrodes, display a featureless quasirectangular CV curve in the N2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte. In contrast, in an O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte, a considerably high current reduction peak emerges at a potential of ~0.75 V versus RHE. While a relatively limited number of transition metal-based materials have been reported as efficient ORR electrocatalysts, the remarkable ORR activity of the Fe-Co-Ni MOF, as well as the bimetallic Fe-Co MOF and the Fe MOF, is of paramount importance for practical applications. Furthermore, the smaller the amount of the potential gap between ORR and OER, the higher the bifunctional OER/ORR activity will be. ΔE OER-ORR of the Fe-Co-Ni MOF catalyst (which is generally the difference between the OER potential at a current density of 10 mA cm-2 and the half-wave potential of ORR at a rotation speed of 1600 rpm) is 0.73 V (a), which is lower than or comparable to those of other catalysts used in zinc-air batteries and outperforms those of expensive noble metal-based catalysts (Table S5).

elements.content: We investigated the ORR activity of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF as well as the Fe–Co MOF, the Fe MOF, and Pt/C control samples via hydrodynamic voltammetry on a glassy carbon (GC) RDE in an O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte. Hydrodynamic voltammetry provides more insights into the kinetic properties of the ORR activities. We recorded polarization curves of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF/GC, the Fe–Co MOF/GC, the Fe MOF/GC, and Pt/C/GC on an RDE at various rotation speeds of 400, 625, 900, 1225, 1600, and 2025 rpm in an O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte (Figure S31). b displays the LSV polarization curves of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF/GC, the Fe–Co MOF/GC, the Fe MOF/GC, and Pt/C/GC at a rotation speed of 1600 rpm. We extracted thermodynamic information such as the onset potential (E onset) and the half-wave potential (E 1/2) for all catalysts from the polarization curves presented in b and summarized in Figure S32. b shows that the Fe–Co–Ni MOF/GC exhibits the best ORR catalytic performance compared to the Fe–Co MOF and the Fe MOF catalysts with a highly positive E onset of 0.82 V and E 1/2 of 0.75 V (vs RHE). These values are slightly less than those of a Pt/C reference catalyst (E onset = 0.91 V, and E 1/2 = 0.85 V vs RHE). We used the Koutechy–Levich (KL) equation to obtain kinetic information about the ORR activity of the catalysts, such as the number of electrons (n) and the kinetic current density (J K). Figure S32a shows the comparison of the KL plots for the Fe–Co–Ni MOF/GC, the Fe–Co MOF/GC, the Fe MOF/GC catalyst, as well as Pt/C/GC as a reference. Figure S32b shows the kinetic parameters along with the half-wave potential and the onset potential at a rotation speed of 1600 rpm for all the catalysts. The number of electrons transferred by Fe–Co–Ni MOF per O2 molecule was estimated to be 3.77, suggesting a nearly four-electron reduction pathway. The exceptional catalytic activity of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF can be attributed to the well-ordered porous structure, excellent distribution of active sites, synergistic effects between them, and sufficient diffusion channels to effectively enhance the mass transport of ionic species within the framework structure.

elements.content: We conducted DFT calculations to gain deeper fundamental insights into the ORR reaction mechanism catalyzed by the Fe–Co–Ni MOF. As reported in the literature, the ORR process can be proceeded via either 4e– or 2e– reaction pathways. The 4e– reaction pathway is associated with the generation of four intermediates, namely O2*, OOH*, O*, and OH*, whereas the 2e– pathway occurs via the generation of just the OOH* intermediate. The product of the 4e– pathway is OH– in alkaline solutions (H2O in acidic solutions) and that of the 2e– pathway is H2O2.
elements.clean_text: We conducted DFT calculations to gain deeper fundamental insights into the ORR reaction mechanism catalyzed by the Fe-Co-Ni MOF. As reported in the literature, the ORR process can be proceeded via either 4e- or 2e- reaction pathways. The 4e- reaction pathway is associated with the generation of four intermediates, namely O2*, OOH*, O*, and OH*, whereas the 2e- pathway occurs via the generation of just the OOH* intermediate. The product of the 4e- pathway is OH- in alkaline solutions (H2O in acidic solutions) and that of the 2e- pathway is H2O2.

elements.content: Figure S33 shows the energy diagram of the 4e– and 2e– ORR pathways on the Fe–Co–Ni MOF at U = 1.23 V. The OOH* intermediate is a common intermediate of the 4e– and 2e– ORR pathways, and the reaction product depends on the bond strength of OOH* on the catalyst surface. Our results demonstrate that the binding energy of oxygen on the Fe–Co–Ni MOF is stronger than that of OOH*, which is favorable for the formation of O*. Moreover, the free energy of H2O2 is −0.91 eV, whereas that of O* + OH– is −1.42 eV. The last one that has OH– (H2O) as a product is a thermodynamically stable pathway, which implies that the thermodynamically favorable 4e– pathway is the dominating mechanism for the ORR on the Fe–Co–Ni MOF that is in agreement with our experimental results (n = 3.77).

The last one that has OH- (H2O) as a product is a thermodynamically stable pathway, which implies that the thermodynamically favorable 4e- pathway is the dominating mechanism for the ORR on the Fe-Co-Ni MOF that is in agreement with our experimental results (n = 3.77).

elements.content: Although the free energies of most steps in the ORR are negative, the reduction from O2* to OOH* is an endothermic reaction. Consequently, this step (with a 0.67 eV free energy, close to the experimental onset potential of 0.89 V) can be considered as a rate-determining step.

elements.content: Considering the point that the charging process of Zn–air batteries involves OER (the backward reaction of ), and the discharge process is driven by insertion of external oxygen and its reduction on the air cathode (i.e., ORR, the forward reaction of ), exploration of advanced bifunctional (OER/ORR) electrocatalysts as cathodes of Zn–air batteries is of critical importance. The results obtained from the ORR and OER studies indicate that the Fe–Co–Ni MOF is a practically applicable bifunctional OER/ORR catalyst, an advantageous characteristic that paves the way for its useful application in state-of-the-art metal–air batteries.

The results obtained from the ORR and OER studies indicate that the Fe-Co-Ni MOF is a practically applicable bifunctional OER/ORR catalyst, an advantageous characteristic that paves the way for its useful application in state-of-the-art metal-air batteries.

elements.content: We assembled a Zn–air battery using Zn powder as an anode and Fe–Co–Ni MOF as an air-cathode according to the scheme shown in c. We also fabricated a control device using a Pt/C + RuO2 air cathode. d displays charge–discharge polarization curves and power density profiles of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF and Pt/C + RuO2 cathodes. The Fe–Co–Ni MOF shows an open-circuit voltage (OCV) as high as 1.424 V, just slightly less than that of Pt/C + RuO2 (OCV = 1.440 V). However, Fe–Co–Ni MOF possesses a smaller potential gap between charge and discharge curves, indicating its better rechargeability compared to the Pt/C + RuO2-based Zn–air battery. Interestingly, at higher current densities the Fe–Co–Ni MOF significantly outperforms the Pt/C + RuO2 electrode (d). The Fe–Co–Ni MOF delivers a maximum power density as high as 161 mW cm–2, whereas Pt/C + RuO2 provides a peak power density of just 138 mW cm–2. In addition, the Fe–Co–Ni MOF-based Zn–air battery delivers an outstanding specific capacity of 733.3 mA h gZn –1 (based on the consumed Zn) at a current density of 5 mA cm–2 with a corresponding specific energy of ∼945 W h kgZn –1, whereas the device based on the Pt/C + RuO2 cathode displays a specific capacity of 664.4 mA h gZn –1 and a specific energy of 900 W h kgZn –1 at the same current density of 5 mA cm–2 (e). The Zn–air battery based on the Fe–Co–Ni MOF also displays a superb rate capability and delivers an output voltage of 1.32 V at a current density of 5 mA cm–2 that decreases to 1.15 V at 50 mA cm–2 and returns to 1.28 V (∼97% of the initial output voltage) at 5 mA cm–2 over the course of about 11 h working (f). To demonstrate the practical applicability and prospects of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF as the cathode for a Zn–air battery, we connected two devices in series that provide an OCV of each 1.424 V (Figure S34a). Two devices connected in series are capable of turning on a digital 3.0 V clock (Figure S34c), powering 52 green (2.2 V) light-emitting diodes (LEDs, g), lighting a blue (2.8 V) LED (Figure S34d, Video S2), and running a rotor for ∼270 s (Video S3).

elements.content: We assessed the long-term cycling stability of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF-based Zn–air battery as well as the Pt/C + RuO2-based control device by recording consecutive galvanostatic charge–discharge measurements at a fixed current density of 5 mA cm–2 with a 10 min cycle time (h). The Fe–Co–Ni MOF-based battery displays excellent stability over 700 cycles that is about five times more durable than the Pt/C + RuO2 benchmark (tolerating only 120 cycles, Figure S35a). For the Fe–Co–Ni MOF-based battery, the overpotential increased from 0.46 V for the first cycle to 0.56 V for the 700th cycle (Figure S35b). As a result, 94.4% of the initial energy was retained even after 120 h of cycling, whereas the Pt/C + RuO2-based battery quickly lost its catalytic activity toward ORR and OER, which caused a severely degraded energy efficiency upon cycling (Figure S35a). Based on the obtained results, the outstanding performances and cycling stability of the Zn–air battery employing the Fe–Co–Ni MOF air cathode can be ascribed to the following factors: (1) the rich porous architecture of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF enables catalytically active sites, which are fully and easily accessible to the electrolyte meanwhile enhancing the escape rate of the O2 and H2 bubbles; (2) the high stability of the Fe–Co–Ni MOF guarantees its long-term catalytic activity toward OER/ORR.

elements.content: Finally, we explored the property of methanol tolerance. In the case of Pt/C, the current density dramatically decreases after the addition of methanol (2.0 M), while the Fe–Co–Ni MOF shows considerable tolerance against the addition of methanol with no noticeable change in current density (Figure S36). This indicates that the platinum catalyst, in addition to being expensive, is highly prone to surface poisoning, which is an additional barrier for using it in energy storage and conversion devices.
